section.title: Terminology and notation

note.p: Eigenvectors and eigenvalues go together in pairs, with the connection between the two provided by the equality A\uvec{x}=\lambda\uvec{x}. In this situation, we say that the two objects correspond to each other. So we might say that \uvec{x} is an eigenvector of A that corresponds to the eigenvalue \lambda. Equivalently, we might say that \lambda is an eigenvalue of A that corresponds to the eigenvector \uvec{x}. However, note that an eigenvalue can correspond to many eigenvectors (in fact, an infinite number of them), an eigenvector must correspond to exactly one eigenvalue.

li.p: the subspace of \R^n consisting of all eigenvectors of A that correspond to a specific eigenvalue \lambda, along with the zero vector
notation for the eigenspace of matrix A corresponding to the eigenvalue \lambda

note.p: In other resources you may seem the terms characteristic vectorcharacteristicvector, characteristic valuecharacteristicvalue, and characteristic spacecharacteristicspace used in place of the terminology introduced above.
